Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: How faithfully are melt embayments wedded to magma ascent?
Award.AbstractNarration: Explosive eruptions can cause wide-ranging societal impacts. The explosivity of a volcanic eruption is controlled in part by how fast magma rises in the conduit. Directly measuring magma ascent is challenging because it takes place underground and in a dangerous environment. Small blebs of frozen magma trapped in crystals, called embayments, may preserve a record of ascent rate in the form of chemical diffusion gradients that scientists can apply as a kind of magma speedometer. This embayment technique has been increasingly used to understand the dynamics of ancient volcanic eruptions. As this speedometer technique grows in popularity, validating its accuracy is important. Here, a series of laboratory experiments conducted using real magma at magmatic temperatures and pressures will recreate magma ascent under controlled conditions to test how well embayments record this process. Careful comparison between the controlled lab conditions and the diffusion gradients in the experimental embayments will clarify “if” and “how?” embayments faithfully record magmatic ascent. Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in research methods at CUNY and Baylor. In addition, public outreach will be performed at the National Museum of Natural History and the NY Virtual Volcano Observatory in the form of “Scientist-is-In” sessions and short-format educational videos on magma ascent. <br/><br/>Quantifying the rate of magma ascent in the volcanic conduit is critical to understanding the timing, magnitude, and behavior of eruptions. Quenched pockets of melt preserved within embayments are thought to preserve such rates as compositional gradients controlled by diffusive equilibration. Past studies using embayments to determine magma ascent rates have used a few, carefully selected samples and have made reasonable, but untested, assumptions involving diffusion and decompression pathway. The key assumptions underlying embayment geospeedometry must be experimentally validated before it can be confidently used to advance the understanding of volcanic eruption dynamics. Here, the theoretical basis for embayment geospeedometry will be systematically tested against focused suites of natural samples and a series of decompression experiments using natural and synthetic embayments. Important tests include (1) discovering how well a single embayment represents a batch of magma, and (2) whether observed diffusion profiles match those predicted from experimental conditions and key assumptions. If the experimental embayments are shown to be robust, then embayment geospeedometry will become a valuable tool for understanding the conditions in volcanic conduits during eruption. If experimental diffusion profiles are instead shown to not match those predicted by experimental conditions then the experiments will provide an empirical framework for exploring the complexities recorded by embayments.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Volcanic crystals are somtimes marked by imperfections that occur as holes that penetrate into the crystal interior. These imperfections are called embayments, and they can be filled with glass, glass+bubbles, or just bubbles. We documented the shape and textures in embayments in our first publication which was led by MS student Anna Ruefer (Frontiers in Earth Science, Ruefer et al. 2021). We were suprised to learn that embayment textures are much more complicated than previously thought. In our second study we focused on quartz-hosted embayments found in the deposits from the large eruption of the Mesa Falls Tuff from Yellowstone caldera. This effort was distributed equally among MS student Anna Ruefer and postdocs Chelsea Allison and James Thompson (EPSL Befus et al. 2023). We were the first to measure dissolved H2O and CO2in embayment glass using high resolution synchroton FTIR. The increased resolution allowed us to map compositions in 2D in the embayment interiors, which we then modelled using the freely available numerical model developed by James Thompson. Our datasets showed that large amounts of CO2 fluxed through the magmatic system prior to eruption. When the eruption began it kicked off with a period of slow, fluid-saturated decompression that preceded rapid ascent during the caldera-forming eruption. As a team we have 2 additional completed studies that have not yet been published. In the the first Chelsea Allison led a synchrotron FTIR exploration of quartz-hosted embayments from the Kos Plateau Tuff in Greece. We show that H2O gradients in those embayments record fast magmatic ascent during eruption, far faster than we determined for Mesa Falls. The final manuscript funded by this grant describes an unexpected discovery: Mesa falls embayment glasses are modified by enrichments from secondary hydration. We show that the secondary hydration was produced after the eruption ended, mostly likley during ~40 years of hydrothermal activity in the cooling Mesa Falls ignimbrite. 

We are proud of the research we completed during the lifetime of this grant. We acknowlege, however, that we did not accomplish all of the goals we initally proposed. Experimental validation of embayment processes has remained elusive. We sought to produce H2O concentration gradients in synthetic embayments that match imposed pressure, temperature, and decompression rates. Although we designed multiple experiments, and performed dozens of experiments, none performed to our standards. The task is not insurmountable, and is a challenge I'll continue to work on. 

The funds in this grant were also used to address societal needs via Broader Impacts. Foremost among them was support for MS student Anna Ruefer, postdoc James Thompson, and postdoc Chelsea Allison. We engaged in various educational outreach activities, both in person and online.
